message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left flank pain, increased urinary frequency, and tenderness to percussion along the left flank. The pain when her left hip is passively extended suggests psoas muscle involvement. The presence of diabetes mellitus also predisposes the patient to psoas muscle abscess. The absence of abnormalities on abdominal ultrasound rules out nephrolithiasis and uterine leiomyoma. Ectopic pregnancy is unlikely given the negative urine pregnancy test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pyelonephritis, and the tenderness to percussion along the left flank suggests an abscess, specifically a psoas muscle abscess. All other options are unlikely given the patient’s symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left flank pain, increased urinary frequency, and tenderness in the left lower quadrant, which suggests a possible psoas muscle abscess. The fact that there is tenderness when the left hip is passively extended is also indicative of a psoas abscess. The patient's poorly controlled diabetes might be related to this as it increases the risk of infections. The fact that there is 3+ glucose in her urine also supports the diagnosis of a possible abscess. Ultrasound may not be sufficient to detect a psoas abscess, so further imaging studies such as CT or MRI may be needed to confirm the diagnosis. Ectopic pregnancy, nephrolithiasis, and uterine leiomyoma are less likely given the patient's symptoms and findings on physical exam.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left flank pain and increased urinary frequency, which suggests urinary tract infection. However, the tenderness to percussion along the left flank and pain when left hip is extended suggest psoas muscle abscess. The absence of abnormalities on ultrasound does not rule out the possibility of a psoas abscess.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left flank pain and increased urinary frequency, which may indicate a urinary tract infection. The tenderness to percussion along the left flank and pain when the left hip is passively extended may indicate a psoas muscle abscess, which can occur in patients with diabetes and is a potential complication of urinary tract infections. The fact that there is no abnormality seen on ultrasound suggests that the abscess is not yet large enough to be visible. None of the other options mentioned are consistent with this patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left flank pain and increased urinary frequency with tenderness in the left lower quadrant and left flank. The tenderness to percussion along the left flank and pain when the left hip is passively extended suggest a psoas muscle abscess. The lack of abnormal findings on ultrasound does not rule out this diagnosis. The presence of 3+ glucose in the urine suggests that the patient's poorly controlled diabetes may have contributed to the development of the abscess. None of the other answer choices present symptoms consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection, which is more common in diabetic patients. The tenderness and pain in the left lower quadrant and left flank, as well as pain in the left hip when extended, suggests psoas muscle abscess. Nephrolithiasis may cause flank pain but is less likely in this case as the ultrasound showed no abnormalities of the kidney. Ectopic pregnancy and uterine leiomyoma are less likely in this case as the patient has a negative pregnancy test and no gynecological complaints.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of left flank pain and increased urinary frequency, along with tenderness to percussion along the left flank and pain with hip extension, suggest a psoas muscle abscess. The lack of findings on the ultrasound does not rule out this diagnosis. The presence of 3+ glucose in the urine suggests poorly controlled diabetes mellitus as a contributing factor. Ectopic pregnancy would present with missed periods and positive pregnancy test. Nephrolithiasis would present with hematuria and the absence of glucose in urine. Uterine leiomyoma would not cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left flank pain and increased urinary frequency, which suggests a urinary tract infection. The tenderness in the left hip when passively extended and the high leukocyte count suggest a psoas muscle abscess, which can occur as a complication of a urinary tract infection in patients with poorly controlled diabetes. The other options are less likely based on the presented symptoms and findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including flank pain, increased urinary frequency, and tenderness to percussion along the left flank, suggest left psoas muscle abscess. Ectopic pregnancy can cause left lower quadrant pain but would not explain the increased urinary frequency or tenderness to percussion along the left flank. Nephrolithiasis can cause flank pain but would not explain the left-sided hip pain. Uterine leiomyoma would not cause any of the presented symptoms.
